speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: I said, when I get home, I get home, and I hung up on her. So now she's pissed and she's texting. "OK, so why do you have to bite my head off?" I told her she should've married a plumber. 9:00 to 5:00, OK? Weekends off, OK?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: He texts her back. This fight actually continues for the next few hours over text message. Then, at 6:57, two hours before closing, one of the managers, Mike Perez, and Jason start huddling the desk, a little freaked out.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Mike walks to Freddie's office to explain the problem to Freddie. Their count is wrong. They're not at 129 because there's an extra chip on the board.

speaker: mike perez
utterance: There was a chip up here that was supposed to be pulled off.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: What do you mean? We're down one?

speaker: mike perez
utterance: Yeah. This was up there. It should have been off of there because the customer switched cars. But someone put the new chip up but didn't take the old chip off.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: So I'm still at 128?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Freddie does know that, at this moment, there is another deal being negotiated that could possibly get them back up to 129. Peter is the salesman for that one. But the deal is stuck over the price of the customer's trade-in, what they should pay for it.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Go make that deal right now. Whatever it is, just make the fucking deal.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: But that deal is not too easy to settle. And while they're waiting, more bad news. You remember that red Grand Cherokee that Scott and Mike Lester each had sold to different people and then Mike Lester's guy dropped out and Scott got the deal, and there was the kiss? Now Scott's guy also drops out. He doesn't want to buy tonight because he wants his mom to see the car tomorrow.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Freddie overhears Scott saying this to one of the managers.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: What, you have a problem? What's the matter with it? What's the matter with it, Scotty?

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: The guy wants to show his mom tomorrow the car. Originally--

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: What do you mean? This isn't a deal?

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: I thought it was, but--

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Are you fucking kidding me? You have insurance on this car and everything?

speaker: scott froehlich
utterance: I don't even-- he didn't even send it into the bank because we don't have his prior employer.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: What are we doing? I thought these all went into the bank today! I asked you, all the cars have insurance and went into the bank? You've got to be fucking kidding me!

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Scott's deal is dead. They're at 127 with just two hours left before closing.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: I'm fucked. I just lost Scott's. I'm fucked.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: So now they scramble to figure out, OK, there was Mike Lester's customer for that red Grand Cherokee. Could they possibly give him better terms that would bring him back to the table? Freddie orders one of the managers, Mike Perez, to make that happen.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Just do it. It's going to be too late. You're going to wait a half hour longer. It's getting later and later. I'd rather have a sure thing than not. Just fucking do it. How much does that lose?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Yeah. The only question is, how much does the deal lose, not whether it loses. So Mike Perez calls Richie in finance. Richie tells him he's in luck. The guy actually called back saying that he would agree to the terms but-- OK, here's the catch-- he just wants 24 hours to think about this. Mike Perez asks, OK, if we sweeten the terms, can we get him to decide right now? Rich doesn't think so.

speaker: rich
utterance: It's not going to change anything tonight. For me to pull down my pants, you don't need to.

speaker: mike perez
utterance: But Freddie's telling me to. Literally, he's telling me to, so I need to just--

speaker: rich
utterance: Bro, whatever you need to do. But I'm telling you, if I told him it was free and the same, you're going to get the same answer anyway-- 24 hours.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: All is lost.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And then, in just six minutes, they turn it around. Rich offers a better deal to that guy on the red Grand Cherokee after all and yes, he takes it. And Peter's deal that was stuck over the price of the trade-in gets unstuck when the managers suck it up and pay $1,500 more for the trade-in than they think it's worth. Back to 129.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Everybody seems a little stunned by what just happened when it's done. Freddie and Sal look out at the showroom from the desk like old sailors on the deck of a 19th century ship that just got thrashed around by a hurricane and also a murderous white whale.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Do you believe this shit, Sal? I feel like back in fucking Infiniti days.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: Oh, my god.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: This is ridiculous, this month.

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: Oh, my god.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: This is just--

speaker: sal lanzilotta
utterance: The month wasn't bad enough. We've got to suffer a little more the last day of the month.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: Un-fucking-believable. Fuck me.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Freddie's phone, of course, doesn't stop with the text messages through all this.

speaker: freddie hoyt
utterance: [SIGHS] God damn. The wife, who else? I don't know what she's even fighting for.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: They get their bonus from Chrysler, $68,000. And because of it, the dealership ends up in the black, not the red, for the month. Jason finishes the month at 29 cars, almost twice anyone else, as usual. Manny has 10; Mike L, 15; Scott, 18.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: The used car side, Joe Monti's side, did not meet its goal. They were hoping for 70. They got 57, meaning Joe Monti probably will not be getting his year-end bonus this year.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And Bob T, the salesman at the bottom of the board with the least sales this month, well, the night isn't over for Bob T.

speaker: bob tantillo
utterance: Where'd you put the key? Where'd you put the car? I've got the key. Where's the car?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Not long after they reached 129, a couple walks in wanting to buy a Dodge Dart for their 19-year-old son. Bob T rushes them through the test drive, has the husband sit at his computer and use his phone to quickly call the insurance company and then runs-- literally runs-- to get their new car prepped and inspected in the garage.

speaker: speaker 1
utterance: Bob, is this one going tonight?

speaker: bob tantillo
utterance: He says to bring it right over to service.

speaker: speaker 1
utterance: Yeah, but is it going, or is it a paper delivery?

speaker: bob tantillo
utterance: I don't know if it's going.

speaker: speaker 2
utterance: Find out.

speaker: bob tantillo
utterance: It should go.

speaker: speaker 1
utterance: Who the fuck wants to take a car home at 10 o'clock at night? You still got the receipt for them? Bring them back!

speaker: bob tantillo
utterance: These guys could say what they want. This old timer, nobody works as fast as me here. You notice that? Huh? Yes or no?

speaker: ira glass
utterance: And with that, Bob T lands Town & Country's last sale of the month, number 130, one car past the goal of 129. Or anyway, that's what they thought that night. The next morning, when everybody comes in, they look at Chrysler's official count on the computer. And according to Chrysler, no, their count was wrong. One of their sales should not have been counted in October, which means that they did not have 130 cars like they thought. They had only 129, exactly 129. Which means, yes, it was Bob T and his very last sale of the month that took them across the finish line. Bob T saved the day.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Special thanks to Marc Brodlieb and the entire staff at Town & Country Jeep Chrysler Dodge Ram in Levittown for letting us hang out for days and barely ever suggesting during that time that one of us might help them reach their goal for the month by buying a new Grand Cherokee. We sent a photographer who does celebrity photographs-- his name is Jeff Minton-- out to Levittown to photograph the sales staff at Town & Country. You can see the results at our website, thisamericanlife.org.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Today's program was produced by Robyn Semien and myself with Alex Blumberg, Ben Calhoun, Sarah Koenig, Miki Meek, Jonathan Menjivar, Brian Reed, Alissa Shipp, and Nancy Updike. Our senior producer for this episode was Julie Snyder. Production help from BA Parker and Diane Wu. Matt Tierney is our technical director.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: This American Life is delivered to public radio stations by PRX, the Public Radio Exchange. Thanks, as always, to our program's co-founder, Mr. Torey Malatia. On a vacation this month in Rome, he stood in line for three hours-- three hours-- at the Colosseum then gave up, went back to his hotel.

speaker: hannibal
utterance: At this point, the Romans will think they have won. Let them taste victory.

speaker: ira glass
utterance: Don't worry. He'll be back. I'm Ira Glass. We will also be back next week with more stories of This American Life.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Last year, Kevin got his mom gloves for Christmas and a hat. And his twin sister, Karyn, what did she get their mom?

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: I got her a pair of leather gloves, I think. Yeah. I got them before Kevin, so I was kind of angry with him, because--

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Oh, because you knew that she got leather gloves?

ep-514.speaker: kevin
ep-514.utterance: No. I didn't know. So then she asked me what I was getting my mom. And then I was like, I got her gloves. And she was like, no, I got her gloves. And I'm like-- yeah. So that's why I got her the hat was because she got gloves, and then I had to go get something else.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Now, to be clear, he still gave her the gloves. So basically, he gave their mom the same present that Karyn gave her mom plus a hat, which might sound like he totally trumped Karyn's gift for the mom, except--

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: I got leather gloves, though. So it's kind of different.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Oh, yours were nicer.

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: Yeah, mine were nicer. I got leather.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: He had to add a hat to rise to the level of her leather gloves. The French essayist Roland Barthes once wrote that when people say I love you, it usually doesn't mean the thought, I love you. And I think what he was saying was that more often when we say I love you, what we mean by it is, I need to get off the phone right now, mom. Or let's stop fighting. Or I'm not loving you right this very second, but I definitely do feel love in a more general and bigger way that I want to acknowledge with these words.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: And giving a Christmas present, I think, is a lot like that. Sometimes it means I love you, right? I want you to have this. I love you. But a hat that you get from your teenage son, it can mean all kinds of things.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: I bought the LEGO Star Wars Defender Class Cruiser for a little kid this year. And what I meant by it was I love you. I definitely meant I love you. But I also meant I know that your mom and dad just split up, and I feel like I should be flying out to California more often to see you. And I feel guilty about not doing that more. And I know that that is a lot of feelings to be putting on to 927 little plastic bricks. Or, you know, take the gift that Kevin got his dad last year.

ep-514.speaker: kevin
ep-514.utterance: I got him some hammers because he was low on hammers. And he's good with his hands, and he likes to build stuff. So I got him some nice hammers.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: How'd that go over?

ep-514.speaker: kevin
ep-514.utterance: He likes them.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: I don't have to take his word for this. We're at the Arundel Mills Mall outside Baltimore, and Kevin's dad, JD, is standing right there. They're doing Christmas shopping.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Do you remember the hammers?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: I do. He lost all the other ones, so his mother made him buy me hammers to replace the ones that were all gone. But they were all gone. So he brought me an assortment of hammers.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: And have you used them?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: Yes, I have.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Are they nice?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: They're hammers, you know.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Not that JD is ungrateful. JD likes the hammers. JD has five kids. He loves all the presents that his kids get him, all the presents. Karyn remembers a present that she made for her dad back when she was eight or nine.

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: I had these two pieces of wood. I chopped them up into little squares. They weren't really good squares. And then I painted little dots on them and made them into dice.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Are you sure he was disappointed in them, or did you just feel like it was a crappy present?

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: It was a crappy present. He couldn't just throw it away. I think that he was trying not to hurt my feelings.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Well, now years have passed. She's almost twice as old. Like, do you want to say what you honestly felt about those dice?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: Very unique. Very unique.

ep-514.speaker: karyn
ep-514.utterance: Isn't it crappy, though?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: Oh, no. It's not. They're handmade. I'll never let go of them, OK?

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Where are they?

ep-514.speaker: jd
ep-514.utterance: In my library in a display case.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: OK. This sounds like it can't possibly be true. But both kids insist that, yes, he is not being sarcastic. He saves everything, has big display cases with old presents and toys in them. But, you know, if your parents are fine with any crappy gift, that poses another problem.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: We got some stuff for our parents. My mom, she got lotion. My dad, he got some lanyard for his keys and some bottle openers.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Gage and William Ross are at the mall on this particular Sunday before Christmas. They're brothers, and their parents went to the casino that's part of the mall-- yes, there's a casino-- and threw them out here, Gage says, with $60 and instructions to buy them Christmas presents.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: We spent about $20 on their stuff, and then the rest was ours.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: Key chains.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: Candy.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: Lanyard. Chewing gum.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Like the twins, like a dozen other teenagers that I interviewed at the mall, they said that it is just really hard buying for your parents.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: Because they never tell you what they really want.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: They just want you to be there and want you to be happy on Christmas morning. They really-- they don't want anything.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: That seems kind of bad, but it's true.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: I could take that $60 and put it in pennies, and they'd be the happiest people in the world.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: And then they don't care either way. You can get them anything.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: Anything at all.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: I can get them a bag of chew toys, and they'd like it.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: I dare you.

ep-514.speaker: william ross
ep-514.utterance: It's already done.

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: I've done it before. Her birthday, I got her a bag full of dog chew toys, yeah, and Milk Bones.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: And what'd she say?

ep-514.speaker: gage ross
ep-514.utterance: She was like, is this for the dog or for me? And I said, it's for you. And she was like, OK, thank you.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: I could not reach his mom to get her side of the story. But I think, come on, any parent tearing off the wrapping paper and seeing that gift, like, I just think that they just think, like, huh? In this season of gift giving, if it is the thought that counts, OK, what exactly are the thoughts behind most presents?

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Well, they're complicated. Sometimes they're really, really complicated. And today on our radio show, we have stories of people giving gifts, and we have stories especially of people receiving gifts, some of these quite spectacular, and trying to divine the motives of the people who gave them. From WBEZ Chicago, it's This American Life, distributed by Public Radio International, a special holiday show. Stay with us.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Act One, Replacement Clause. So we begin today's show about giving gifts with the gift givingest person that there is. Of course, Santa Claus is that person, a man who wants for nothing, that is, until some things change for him. Jonathan Goldstein explains.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Each life was a lonely tumble down a cold, dark chimney, falling, falling, then blackness. These were Santa's thoughts as he prepared snickerdoodles in the kitchen. In the other room, the elves performed Christmas tunes and do-si-doed.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Carefully, he carried the tray of sweets into the living room. His wife, Martha, had been dead five years now, and he was alone, alone in a house full of elves. Jesus had dignity, apostles. All he had was high blood pressure and a communal toilet the size of a cereal bowl.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: He sat down on the couch and watched the elves dance to "Feliz Navidad." Jingles broke from the group of dancing elves and approached him. "You're killing yourself with the doodles," Jingle said, slamming down his Gin Rickey. And lately, he'd been on Santa's case to stop overeating, to get out of the house, and to get himself a girlfriend.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Glenda, the good witch of the north, lived only a few miles away and had just been left by her boyfriend, a walrus hunter who looked somewhat like a walrus himself. "Glenda's into the Wilford Brimley type," said Jingles, "so you've totally got a chance." "Glenda," said Santa, "but she's so sparkly. I miss Martha," Santa said quietly.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: He knew this was true, though not the entire truth. There was missing, of course, but there was also fear. "Look, I miss Martha too," said Jingles. "But it's time to move on."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "She was the only gal for me," said Santa. Jingles put his tiny hand on Santa's knee. "To be frank," Jingles said, "I always thought your relationship a little narcissistic. Mrs. Claus was like your twin but with bosoms. Did you plan your outfits together?"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "We just had the same taste," Santa sobbed. "Jingle Bell Rock" started up on the squeeze box, and Santa took that as his cue to head to bed. He never could stand rock and roll Christmas songs.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: He liked Christmas songs, and he liked rock and roll. He just didn't like them together. Martha had felt the exact same way. On their first year anniversary, Martha presented him with a pen, the fancy kind that came in a box.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Oh, for the love of Saint Nicholas," Santa had said, "what good is a pen? I'll just end up losing it. Save your money and buy yourself something nice, or let me buy for you. That would make me most happy of all."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: For a man famous for his giving, Santa was terrible at receiving. Martha took the pen back and apologized. And that was the end of the gifts.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: After she had died and Santa was cleaning out her stuff, in a jewelry box filled with the old love letters he'd sent during their courtship, he found the pen. He clutched it on the edge of the bed and wept. Jingles took it upon himself to just go ahead and arrange a date for Santa unbidden.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Glenda's expecting you at eight," said Jingles, sidling up to him in the reindeer stable one morning. "And do me a favor. Trim your whiskers and put on your spanx." As instructed, Santa appeared at Glenda's doorstep that evening, a paper bag of roasted chestnuts in his hand.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Come on in, Mr. Claus," said Glenda with a sweep of her arm. She was dressed all in white, and the house smelled of fresh gingerbread. Santa observed with a smile that there were several magic wands, gold and sparkly, in the umbrella rack.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: For most of the evening they sat by the hearth and made clumsy conversation about the loneliness of living at the North Pole, mostly. "Unless I absolutely have to, I don't even bother going outside," said Glenda. "And when the cable goes out, it is out," said Santa.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: After a beat of silence, Glenda looked at him, a smile across her face. "Is this a good conversation?" she asked. Santa laughed and assured her it was.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: They played cribbage, drank eggnog, and watched the snow outside the window fall. And in the vestibule, before leaving, Glenda placed her hand on Santa's shoulder and kissed him right beneath his eye. As she did, Santa felt as though his chest were a chimney, and inside a sleeping dove was stirring awake.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: They made a date for the following weekend. And just before he left, Glenda gave him a container of cranberry mini muffins she'd baked. Santa told her he could not accept such a gift, at which point she thrust it into this chest with surprising force. "Take it," she said. On the sleigh ride home, Santa realized with mixed feelings that he'd hardly thought of Martha the whole night.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: When he showed up the following Saturday, Glenda was all apologies. "Change of plans," she said, stopping him in the vestibule. "Sheila's here, flew in this afternoon from Tampa."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Sheila?" asked Santa. "AKA, the wicked witch of the east," she said quickly, "My old college roommate." "College?" asked Santa. "For witches?"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "She's always showing up like this," Glenda went on. "Every time there's trouble in Tampa, I get a knock at the door." In the den, Sheila was lying on the couch in a kittenish tangle, all in black and smoking what smelled like European cigarettes.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: She studied Santa while playing with her hair. "Hey, chubs," she said. "I told you to smoke outside," said Glenda with exasperation. She went into the kitchen to get some fruitcake as Santa made his way over to the couch.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Sheila didn't move. So he squeezed into the corner, her black stocking toes touching his thigh. "So what do you do, fatso?" Santa began to stammer. "Oh, I--"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Relax, [BLEEP]. I know you are. You're famous," she said, taking the last cookie from the serving tray. "So how do you know Glenda?"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "Oh, we're neighbors," said Santa. "And you buy this good witch [BLEEP]?" she asked in a whisper. "A downward turn in the black arts, and all of a sudden she's moved to the North Pole and rebranded herself a good witch. Whoever heard of a good witch, am I right? It's an oxymoron, like baby grand or jolly fat man. Everyone knows fat men are sad. Look at you, totally depressed. Am I right?"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "I mean, maybe a little," Santa said. "My wife recently died." "And what's with this Glenda [BLEEP]?" interrupted Sheila. "Her name's Linda."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Often, when Santa didn't know what else to say, he'd break into a jolly sounding chuckle. He tried it just then, but the chuckle got caught in his throat and came out sounding sweaty and choked. Sheila stared at him.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "You have this weird crap in your beard," she said. She reached in to pull it out, and as she did, she brought her face in close enough for Santa to smell her. Whereas Glenda smelled like baby powder and cinnamon, Sheila smelled of something he couldn't quite put his finger on. Cigarettes, of course, but something else, too. It set the chimney in his chest ablaze, ashy black doves trying to flap out their flaming wings.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: As Sheila rummaged through his beard, the look on her face was all little girl concentration. "You have nice bone structure," she said. "You should try wearing black. It would have a slimming effect."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Withdrawing a tiny shriveled raisin from Santa's beard, Sheila crinkled up her face and flicked it on the carpet. "Eww, gross," she said. Glenda walked back into the room with drinks. And when Santa reached for one, he realized his hand was shaking.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: He excused himself to use the bathroom, where he thought he might hum a few carols to calm himself down. Everything inside the bathroom was glittery and white, white glittery soaps, shampoos, curtains. But there, hanging from the white shower curtain rod, was something black.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Strung there for all the world to see were a pair of silky black stockings, Sheila's black stockings. For years, Santa had dealt intimately with stockings, stuffing them with coal or presents, and never thought about it twice. But just then, seeing those black stockings of hers, being alone with them, something came over him. And suddenly, he was on his toes biting the tips like a playful pup, like a fat old playful pup.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Returning to the living room, Santa sat back down on the couch and listened, enraptured, as Sheila encouraged him to revise his policy on naughtiness. Santa nodded his head as though giving her suggestion some thought. In bed that night, Santa replayed each of Sheila's words and gestures.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Sheila said whatever she felt like, touching and smelling everything like an animal. She was not afraid to take, avail herself of the world, drinks, cigarettes, hospitality. Without so much as asking, she'd even plunged her hand into Santa's Shirley Temple, plucking the maraschino cherry right out and using his hat to wipe her hands.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: For Santa, one so in love with giving, he could not help but see before him a kind of black hole, a sexy and sublime black hole into which he could deliver forth his greatest gift. In Sheila, he saw an insatiable hunger for life. With such a woman to give to, to give himself to, it would feel as though every day was Christmas.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: When they had made plans for the following weekend, Glenda had asked if Santa could bring along a friend for Sheila. And so he showed up with Jingles. Anything to help a brother out, Jingles had said. Strolling into Glenda's living room, Jingles did that thing where he jumped onto the couch while crossing his legs in midair. He landed right beside Sheila.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "You are just too cute for words," exclaimed Sheila. "Try anyway," said Jingles, snipping the tip of his cigar. It was the length of his forearm.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "I'd prefer to keep the house smoke free," said Glenda. "More like fun free," said Sheila. "Say, what do you call people who live around here anyway? North Pollack's?"

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "We call ourselves Cold Poles," said Jingles. "Ever put your tongue on a cold pole, honey? Tends to get stuck there." Sheila slapped him on the head. "Dork," she said, laughing.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Sheila and Jingles had a million things to talk about. All the while, Glenda and Santa just sort of sat there smiling awkwardly and watching the snowfall. "It's an uninhabitable wasteland," Santa heard Sheila say. "Tampa sounds awesome," said Jingles. "If only I could convince El Jefe over there to move the operation south."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Jingles looked over at Santa, and seeing his bro struggling with his date decided to kick things into gear. "Come on y'all," said the elf, addressing the group. "Gather around for a little spin o' the bottle."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "I've got just the one," said Sheila, downing the last of the red wine straight from the bottle. "Spin the what?" asked Glenda. Sheila rolled her eyes, placed the bottle down on the carpet, and spun.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Santa watched the bottle spin with an anxiety that bordered on mania. What if the bottle dictated that he was to kiss Sheila? He would almost certainly die.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: But he did not have to ponder such a kiss for very long, for soon the bottle slowed to a halt, pointing directly at Jingles. And when Sheila licked her lips and leaned her face downward, Jingles grabbed her head in his small hands and planted his tiny mouth on hers. Santa felt the chimney fire in his chest snuff out.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: He and Glenda watched them kiss. Then after a while they watched the snowfall. Then they went back to watching them kiss. Eventually Jingles led Sheila into the vestibule where he said he wanted to show her the secret to getting the tips of his shoes so curly.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Left alone, and at somewhat of a loss, Glenda got up and fished around in a cabinet drawer beside the couch. Santa thought she might be looking for a game of some sort. But then she said," "I have something for you."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: She held out a glistening package. "No way, Jose," Santa said. "I'm the gift giver around here. And it's not even Christmas yet."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Santa was about to really kick up a fuss. But then, as a downright witchy look fell across Glenda' face, he trailed off. "It's nothing that big," she insisted, thrusting the present at his chest. "Besides, it was fun trying to find the perfect something for you. And then to actually find it, there's no greater feeling in the world. But look who I'm telling this to."

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Hearing her words and seeing the look of excitement on her face, Santa had a puzzling thought. Perhaps he'd somehow misjudged things. Perhaps he'd somehow gotten it wrong.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: By refusing the gifts people wished to bestow on him, he'd consistently failed to give the experience of giving. He'd hogged that particular pleasure all to himself. And so he took the package. It was flat and square.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: Tearing the wrapping paper open, he saw it was a record, Rocking Christmas Party Songs, Volume One. He absolutely hated it. Not just because the thought of listening to it made him feel like one of those old white haired hippies who had to make everything, from getting their prostate checked to celebrating Christmas, not just a good time but a rocking good time. But it was also one of those gifts that said something about the recipient, something that was hard to swallow, like the gift of a back scratcher that says you're alone in this world and must fend for yourself or the gift of a warm house coat that says your days of party dresses are over.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: The gift of a perfectly awful Christmas album being handed to you by a woman who liked you said loud and clear, you must learn to compromise. For after all his years of giving, Santa knew better than anyone that we don't always receive what we want nor even what we deserve. We receive what life brings us. And when it comes to life, we haven't a choice but to open our arms.

ep-514.speaker: jonathan goldstein
ep-514.utterance: "I love it," said Santa with a half smile. Unpeeling the plastic, they placed the album on the record player. Santa held out his arms, and Glenda entered his embrace. And together, they danced about the room as Chuck Berry belted out "Run Rudolph Run." And it was almost enough to drown out the sounds in the vestibule.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: So do you know what you're getting your parents for Christmas?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Not yet. I've never been good at this kind of thing. As I'm getting older, it's like I'm supposed to have some money so I can actually buy them a nice enough gift where it's not just, you know.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Do you remember what you got them last year?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I believe I got my dad a Sons of Anarchy t-shirt.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: This is Larry Daniels, 19 years old, goes to community college, doesn't have a job. He got his mom Cowboys memorabilia last year.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I believe it was lounging pants.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: That's like sweatpants?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Yes, kind of. They're like sweatpants, only made of a thinner material, I believe.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: And you've seen her in them?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Yes, I have. She loves to lounge.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Did you see him in the Sons of Anarchy t-shirt?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I don't believe I've ever seen him wear it. But he may have worn it-- as I'm getting older, I'm starting to realize my memory's fading as it goes on. But they were generally happy with the present that I got them because-- yep.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: You have no idea what you're going to get them at all.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: No, I do not. I feel like I may never find something in time, you know? I'm just so lost.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Could you just ask them what they want?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I could.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: But it sounds like-- it's funny talking to you. It sounds like it's never occurred to you just to ask them.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: That's true. I'm not a question asking person. I'm just usually-- I get nervous.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: So you've never asked them, what do you want for Christmas?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: No, I don't think I have. I don't know. It just feels like if ask them, they'll tell me. And, like, OK, they'll expect to get it, you know?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Because a lot of times when you watch, like, TV shows or movies where a kid-- their birthday is coming up. And they're like, oh, I want this. I want this. I'm probably going to get it, because I've said I want this.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: But then they don't get it. They're disappointed. I'm, like, OK, maybe they'll be the same way. But I don't know.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: But wait. But you could get them what they want.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I could. Yes, I could. Actually, yeah, I probably could. Maybe. Yeah, maybe.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Do you think that they would ask you for something that you wouldn't be able to get them?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: I don't know. They might, actually. But I've never been in that situation. Or I may have been. Maybe once or twice I've been in that situation, and I got them something else, like, say, a mug, like a coffee mug or one of those kind of mugs that you see in a bar almost, only plastic, like a freezable mug, I guess.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: You mean like a mug for beer?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Yes.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: So wait. So this is a present you actually got them.

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Yes, I did get my mom a mug one year.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: How'd that go?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: She loved it. I mean, I just thought, this is cool. I'll get her this, you know? That's usually what I do when I see a present. I'm like, this is cool. I'll get them this. That's kind of how I go through things, you know?

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: So you're here at the mall. You're going to wander around until something hits you?

ep-514.speaker: larry daniels
ep-514.utterance: Yes. It's worked well so far. Usually. But hopefully it'll work this time again.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Coming up, over 600 boxes, gifts from decades ago opened one by one. That's in a minute, from Chicago Public Radio and Public Radio International, when our program continues.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: It's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass. Each week on our program, of course, we choose a theme.

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Today's show, "The Thought That Counts." For this holiday season, we have stories of gifts and what people intend when they send them, which can be very, very complicated. We have arrived at Act Two of our program.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Act Two, Your Junk in a Box. So people, of course, are opening up packages full of treasures all year round, not just at Christmas. And, you know, when it's not members of your family or your friends or anybody who you've ever met who packed the boxes, it can be confusing. Starlee Kine has this story.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: When I was in fifth grade, my class buried a time capsule in the grass that jutted against the school parking lot. We didn't feel like being generous with our gift giving towards future generations. Why should they get our best toys?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: So we only tossed in the Garbage Pail Kid cards that we had doubles of, or jelly bracelets, a 10-year-old's most disposable possession. I can picture the people who will one day stumble upon our capsule. They'll turn our junk over in their hands. It'll be easy to figure out it was buried by children in a spot where there once was a school. But why we chose this crap, what we could have possibly meant by it, that will be the stumper.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: In a museum in Pittsburgh, there's a group of people who spend their days opening time capsules and trying to piece together the original thinking behind each one. These time capsules were all left by one person, Andy Warhol. There are 621 of them.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: He didn't bury them, and they weren't capsule shaped. There were just cardboard boxes filled with his stuff. And what makes them so different than the regular archives left behind by famous artists when they die-- because he also has those-- were that these time capsules, and he did call them time capsules, were deemed one big piece of art.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: All 621 go together as a set. The contents have to stay together, too. Warhol started the project in 1974. He'd fill boxes up with various objects. Each one is packed to the brim, and they take longer to open and go through than you may think.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: The first capsule was opened in 1991. And two decades later, there are still ones that haven't been gotten to yet. The day I visit, the museum has three full-time cataloguers whose jobs are just to open and sort through the boxes, five days a week, eight hours a day, Elaina, Erin, and Marie.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: All three look like they stepped out of a '40s screwball comedy, pencil skirts, black glasses, soft curls. When I arrive, they just opened a new capsule. There's this long conference room table completely covered with the items they found inside.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 1
ep-514.utterance: We have some items signed by Nick Rhodes, Duran Duran lead singer? Guitarist? Somebody in Duran Duran.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 1
ep-514.utterance: Letters from Liza Minnelli. There's also her wedding invitation. There's an invitation to President Reagan's inauguration, which is next to an ashtray that has some Keith Haring artwork, I believe, on it.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: There's a Christmas card from John Waters with a dollar bill in it. There's a note from Bianca Jagger signed with a lipstick kiss. It's so close to what I would imagine Andy Warhol's house being filled with that it feels set up.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: It's as though his friends just walked from room to room drawing on or pressing their lips against anything that was the least bit ordinary. There's also two small drawings by Basquiat just lying there on the table with everything else. One is a portrait he did of Andy while he slept.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: The girls say that this just happened sometimes. All of a sudden they'll stumble upon some priceless art that has never been seen or pieces of Warhol's that were believed to have been lost forever. And then there are the wild cards. This is the museum's director, Eric Shiner.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: eric shiner
ep-514.utterance: Did you see this yet?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: No, what is it?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: eric shiner
ep-514.utterance: I believe that would be Rob Lowe, naked, wrapped in a huge stuffed animal snake. Is there anything on the back?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 2
ep-514.utterance: Yeah, there's a note.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: eric shiner
ep-514.utterance: Let's see. Oh, it's actually signed Rob Lowe. "Andy, thanks so much for all the fun. Don't forget I would love something from you. This is a trade. Thanks again. Call me in LA," with Rob Lowe's phone number. And he's sending this photograph in hopes of getting something from Warhol as a gift in exchange.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: I can't put into words how badly I wanted that Rob Lowe photo. The degree of willpower it took to not slowly, over the course of the afternoon, slide it more and more off the table until it fell to the ground, where I would then stand on it until I was able to drop something else, something less valuable-- my scarf, the microphone-- so as to then be able to stoop down and transfer the photo from the floor to my bag. It wasn't because it seemed worth a lot of money.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: I wanted it for, like, my house, to hang on my fridge. I couldn't understand how we weren't calling the number. When you come across a wallet-size photo of a naked Rob Lowe wrapped in a giant toy snake, which you can tell was done in complete sincerity because of the look on his face, a look that no one but me and the other people in this room would ever see, you do as the photo says and call the number.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: I had questions that needed answering, such as, did he take the photo himself with a timer, or did he have a friend do it? But like everything else, the photo was just put down on the table. And once it was catalogued, back into the box it would go.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Andy Warhol was a major hoarder, known for it. For every original Keith Haring or Basquiat or Rob Lowe, the girls will find piles and piles of junk mail. There was a box full of Eddie Bauer catalogs. And they found actual garbage, like finger nail clippings and rotten sandwiches.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: I found some hair and underpants.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Whose?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: I don't know. But they were dirty. They were horrible, yeah. They were, like, Jockey small briefs.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: How do you know they were dirty?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: It was visible.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: They were stained.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: All of this makes more sense because of how the boxes started. The story goes that in 1974 Warhol was moving his studio from one building in New York to another. The problem was he was notoriously tight with his money, loved buying stuff, hated paying people. And so he didn't hire a moving company.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Warhol told his assistant don't worry about it. He'd just pack everything up himself. But the assistant, fearing that he and the other members of the staff would end up having to do it all themselves, came up with an idea.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: He suggested to Andy that rather than viewing the boring old cardboard packing boxes as just ways to transport his stuff from one place to the next, he should think of them as time capsules. It was exactly the kind of trick you resort to when your kids won't eat their vegetables by making a chore into a game. And it worked. Big time.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Even after the move, Andy kept making the capsules. He kept open cardboard boxes on his desk, in his studio, in his house, filling some up right away, taking years to fill others. He was hooked. He'd found the perfect outlet for his hoarding impulses. Instead of having to throw anything away ever again, he could just stick that thing into a box and call it art.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: We get a lot of confetti and potpourri because the time capsules happened partly in the '80s, and people were fond of mailing invitations with potpourri or confetti.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Confetti and glitter just line the streets in the '80s.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: Yeah. I feel like once a week, one of us opens something with confetti in it, and we're like oh, crap.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Then you have to go and, like, pick up all the individual pieces of confetti?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: Oh, yeah.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: You do? Really?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Every piece of every object is part of the art and has to be officially catalogued. So glitter gets scooped up and put into a container like a film's party scene being rewound. Plastic bags go into other plastic bags. Cassette tapes go unplayed so as not to damage the physical audiotape.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: A sealed deck of cards from Penn and Teller with the secret to a magic trick concealed inside isn't opened so as to preserve the plastic wrapping. The museum's chief archivist, Matt Wrbican, says normally archivists will throw out staples and paper clips. Not here.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: matt wrbican
ep-514.utterance: The paper clips get numbered.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Really?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: matt wrbican
ep-514.utterance: Really.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Do you guys ever feel like suckers for doing it, for buying into it?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: Matt once-- he recently said that this was Andy's joke on the art world. And the three of us were like, that's our job.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 1
ep-514.utterance: So this is typical. We have a few boxes that are like this, that just have vitamin bottles that he was taking at the time, just, like, the empty packaging, 20 or 30 of them in here.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: In this room that's so antiseptic, where the procedures are so set and paperclips become museum objects, we're still dealing with a man's stuff. It's very personal. The girls know that Andy's dry cleaner's name was Danielle and that she was always sending him bills, which he ignored. He did the same with the surgeon who saved his life after he was shot, who they found a note from that read "pay up, you blow hard."

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: But they also know that along with unpaid bills, he would send art donations to charities. They know there were letters from fans asking him to sign an enclosed photo, and the photo will never be there, which means he sent it back to them signed. They know what he looked like without his wig on, that he had a comb over.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: They know that there's a whole box he made devoted to his mom and how that one felt extra personal because some of her clothing was inside, and that can connect you to a person more than anything else. They found Andy's clothing in the capsules too. They know there are certain things you can't learn about a person just through reading, like the actual size of their waist.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: None of the girls say they knew much about Warhol before this job. They're young. One of them says, "um, I knew his name." And so watching them feels like watching three really nice people tenderly unpack a stranger's house.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: And there's more gift wrap.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 2
ep-514.utterance: It's cute.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: There's a lot of gift wrap.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 2
ep-514.utterance: Do you want to open that?

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Under the gift wrap, the girls discover some photos of Andy taken outside.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3
ep-514.utterance: Oh, these are--

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: eric shiner
ep-514.utterance: Oh, nice.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 1
ep-514.utterance: Oh, neat.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 3

ep-514.speaker: starlee kine

ep-514.speaker: starlee kine

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 2

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: cataloguer 2
ep-514.utterance: She sends these great photos of them all just hanging out together. He always looks like he's having fun and relaxed in the photos that she sends. ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: starlee kine
ep-514.utterance: Whatever Warhol intended when he packed these boxes, I think it would have been hard for him to imagine this, that strangers would open them and go through his stuff and be the last people on earth to get to know him this intimately and end up liking him even more than when they started.

ep-514.act_title: Act Two: Your Junk In a Box
ep-514.speaker: ira glass

ep-514.speaker: ira glass
ep-514.utterance: Act Three, Christmas or Bust. Now this story of a Christmas present and a teenager at Christmas trying to do right by his parents. It's a work of short fiction from Russell Banks.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: I didn't go to jail for it or anything. But I think of the time I got caught shoplifting at the lingerie store up at the Champlain Mall in Plattsburgh as the beginning of my life of crime. It was supposed to be the first Christmas after my mother and stepfather kicked me out of the house when I was still 14 and crashing at my friend Russell's place with the bikers down on Water Street in Au Sable Forks.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: They were letting me sleep on this ratty couch they had, because I was dealing weed then and kept them supplied on credit. But mostly when I hung out there, I stayed in Russell's room. The bikers were older than us and were heavier into drugs. I saw one of those guys once rub a line of coke straight into his eye, which kind of grossed me out. Plus they drank a lot.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: Russell was 16 and worked days part time at The Video Den. At nights we used to ride up to the mall in his Camaro so I could deal a little weed to the other kids. And we would hang out until the stores closed and hit on the girls. But mostly nothing was happening, so we'd sit around on the benches and watch all these cheesy couples doing their Christmas shopping, which was pretty depressing.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: At Christmas the malls are filled with people who feel rotten because they don't have enough money, so they fight a lot. The carols and blinking lights and the guys in Santa suits are supposed to make you forget your troubles. But it's the opposite. At least for me it was, which was one of the reasons I liked to get high before we went there.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: This one night, about 10 days before Christmas, I didn't have any weed. And I was thinking about my mother and stepfather, how it would be the first time they would be alone. And I wondered what they'd do on Christmas Eve.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: What they usually did was get smashed on this eggnog and bourbon mixture my mother said was her mother's secret recipe and watch TV specials. Around 11:00 when the news came on, we'd open the presents we got for each other, hug, and say thanks. And then they'd go into their room and pass out. And I'd smoke a joint in the bathroom and watch MTV with Willy, the cat, until I fell asleep.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: It was OK but not exactly ideal. But we had a tree and lights in the windows and all. And last year was cool because I got this excellent suede shearling jacket from my mom. And my stepfather gave me a Timex watch so I could start coming home on time, he said.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: I got her one of those long silk Indian scarves that she seemed to like a lot. And for him I got a pair of lined driving gloves. Everybody was happy in spite of the eggnog.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: But a lot happened since then. For one thing, the main thing, I guess, I got kicked out of the house for stealing and pawning my mother's coin collection that she had inherited from her mother and that she was someday going to pass on to me. But it also had to do with my getting a mohawk and my ears pierced and screwing up in school.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: And even though they never caught me at it, they knew I was heavy into weed, which was why I had stolen the coins in the first place. When I left, it was sort of by mutual agreement, I guess. They would have let me come back if I wanted but only if I could be a different person than I was, which was not only impossible but unfair because I didn't know how to keep myself from getting into trouble anymore.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: I must have crossed the line back when I was a little kid, like five or six, after my real father took off and my stepfather moved in and married my mom. My stepfather was OK. But I know he didn't mind at all when he and mom found out I stole the coins and they got to boot me out of the house. I knew my mother wanted me to come home. But no way I was going back as long as it didn't make the both of them happy to see me.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: So I started imagining this scene. I get Russell to drop me off at my mom's and stepfather's house, which is really only a mobile home except it's got a foundation under it and a deck in back like a regular house. All my stuff, including my trademark dirt bike, is in Russell's car. And we unload and set it on the sidewalk.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: But also, I've got this huge bag of presents for my mom and my stepfather, truly excellent items like a toaster oven and a Crock-Pot and maybe some jewels and a fancy nightgown for mom. And for my stepfather, a Polaroid camera and a portable sander and a Polo ski sweater. Then Russell takes off and I'm alone.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: The house is dark except for the string of lights around the front door and the electric candles in the windows. And I could see the Christmas tree lights blinking through the curtain in the living room where I know they're watching The Cosby Show or something. It's Christmas Eve. It's snowing a little.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: They're really sad because I'm not with them, and they don't know how to let me come home without acting like what I did to them doesn't matter, stealing the coin collection, smoking grass, getting a mohawk and all, and living with Russell and the bikers, and not going to school anymore, which they probably know about by now, and dealing weed for Hector, the Hispanic guy at the Limbo, which they don't know about. Although, I wonder what they think I've been living on all these months, charity? Also, they don't know that so far I haven't gotten a tattoo, even though Russell has two very cool tattoos on his arms and is always after me to get one.

ep-514.speaker: russell banks
ep-514.utterance: Anyhow, in this scene, I go up to the door and knock. And when my mom comes out, I say Merry Christmas, mom, just sort of flat and normal like that, and hold out the bag with all the presents wrapped in this incredible shiny paper with bows and everything. She starts to cry, and my stepfather comes to the door to see what's the matter. I say the same to him. Merry Christmas, Ron, which is what I call him, Ron. And I show him the bag of presents, too.
